bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to George Miller Sternberg, April 17, 1899

div1.p: Agramonte informs Sternberg that during the past several weeks there have been very few cases of yellow fever from which he could obtain material for research. Attached to the letter is a note by Truby stating that Agramonte and Carroll assisted Reed in the lab in 1898.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to George Miller Sternberg, April 17, 1899
div1.p:
1899
HEADQUARTERS
DIVISION OF CUBA
CHIEF SURGEON'S OFFICE.
RECEIVED
APR 18 1899
No. 1537.

YELLOW FEVER HOSPITAL
HAVANA CUBA APR 12th, 1899

OFFICE OF SURGEON GENERAL.
APR 22
G.
38657
WAR DEPARTMENT.
1899

Submits Report on yellow Fever
to the S.G.U.S.A.

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
HAVANA? CUBA, APRIL 18th, 1899
OFFICE OF CHIEF SURGEON.

Respectfully forwarded to the
Surgeon General, U.S.A. Washing
-ton, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to George Miller Sternberg, April 17, 1899
div1.opener:
Agramonte
Yellow Fever Hospital (No 3)
To Brig. Gen. Geo. M. Sternberg U.S.A.
Surgeon General.
Washington D.C.
Havana, April 17 1899.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I ratify mine of the 18th Oct;
There have been very few cases of yellow
fever during the last few weeks, from
which it was possible to obtain material
for research.

Three cases at the Reina Mercedes
Hosp. were examined; two of them
recovered and cultures made from
their blood gave a negative result:
from the third case, a very severe
one with profuse bleeding from the
gums, mouth and nose, I obtained
various organisms among them
bac. icteroides.

Three other cases of reported of
yellow fever were seen but the diagnosis
having been rectified and changed
to something else, work was discontinu-
ed upon them.

A case which occurred on board of
of a vessel in the bay, came to my knowledge
after autopsy had been performed, it was
under the jurisdiction of the Marine Hosp.
Service and Dr. Wasdin and Geddings looked
after it: a subsequent case occurred on
the same vessel and although promised
by Dr. Wasdin, I was not notified.

There are no cases of yellow fever at
present in the city nor among the troops.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully
Aristides Agramonte A.A. Surgeon, U.S.A.

div1.head: Note by Albert E. Truby, [n.d.]
div1.p:
Agramonte was on duty
with Reed in May 1898 at the
A.M.S. Lab. Reed was then
doing work on B. icteroides
and Agramonte & Carroll assisted.
Naturally Agramonte was
still interested when he reached
Cuba (at Siboney and later
at Havana.

In Reed's letter to Gen Sternberg
p. 220, Sternberg Biog, he
refers to Agramonte bacteriological
work.
